post_text: Ralston High School art students pictured are working on infusing two styles of art into one project: Still Life and Contour Line. Each student had to take pictures or bring to school five objects that had some personal meaning to them. They then had to organize their objects into one image to start their drawing. For reference, still life art focuses on still objects, and contour line art is a method of drawing where you draw only the outline of an object, without any shading.

To best serve everyone and to be as safe as possible, we are asking families to please stay in their vehicles during the food distribution.

Families can start to line up in the Ralston High School main front parking lot at 4:00 pm. The food distribution starts at 5:00 pm and concludes at 6:00 pm.

It will be a drive-through distribution, so again you will not need to get out of your car.

Elementary: Linsey Bellinger (Wildewood Elementary School & RHS)

Foundation: Hadassah Schmitt (Lil' & Tiny Rams - Ralston Schools Foundation)

Congratulations to the 2020 Heart of Learning Award winners! They are such a deserving group of people who exemplify leadership, kindness, and passion for what they do. We are so grateful to have them in Ralston! Congrats!

Ralston Schools Foundation
April 28 at 12:56 AM ·

Ralston Schools Foundation is excited to announce the 2020 Heart of Learning Award recipients! These teachers and staff members leave an impact on our kids' lives every single day. They are so deserving of recognition and their nominations make it clear that Ralston Public Schools is a special place!

Congratulations to this year's Award winners:
Elementary: Linsey Bellinger (Wildewood Elementary School & RHS)
Secondary: Cammie Weland (Ralston High School)
Classified: Gary Phillips (Ralston High School)
Foundation: Hadassah Schmitt (Lil' & Tiny Rams - Ralston Schools Foundation)

Congratulations to Ralston High School alumna Dawn Crinklaw Gustafson (1985) on being part of the 2020 class of the Nebraska High School Sports Hall of Fame. The class will be inducted on October 4th at Lincoln East High School. For more information, visit the Hall of Fame website - https://nebhalloffame.org/

Here is more information about Dawn and her outstanding athletic career. Dawn Crinklaw Gustafson: The runner-up for the Dial National High School Athlete of the Year award, she was recruited to play collegiately in four sports, eventually playing basketball and softball at U.S. International in San Diego before playing professional basketball in the United Kingdom and the Netherlands. At Ralston, she was a three-year starter in volleyball and basketball and a two-time all-class gold medalist in the discus.

post_text: The 100 Grid Math Game is popular right now at Mockingbird Elementary School! It started in kindergarten and has caught on in other grades throughout the school. Pictured are fourth and second-grade students enjoying the game. The game is simple, highly competitive and allows students to focus on multiple math skills. Students are grouped together, provided an empty 100 place grid, and a set of dice. The goal for each student is to write all the numbers (0-100) and complete the grid as fast as they can. Students can only write on their grid if they roll matching numbers (rolling a double). You continue to write until another player rolls a double. Then you steal the pencil and start filling your 100 place grid. This goes on until someone completes their grid.

post_text: One of the most memorable experiences for seventh-grade students at Ralston Middle School has to be the Greek Olympics Day! The study of Greek history has been a large part of their Social Studies class but also has involved other subject areas including Language Arts (reading mythological stories), Math (studying Pythagoras), and Science (learning about the Hippocratic Oath). It culminates with an actual Olympic games competition with many students dressed in togas.

Today was Unity Day at Ralston Middle School. Students were encouraged to wear orange in support of kindness, acceptance, inclusion and bullying prevention.

Students welcomed other students to school with a message of "Every step you take can create a kinder, more inclusive and accepting world." They outlined students' footsteps with chalk to make a path into the school. Once inside, students could take an anti-bullying pledge by signing a large #BeKind poster.

Over the lunch hour, students traced their hands and wrote a message of how they could be kind to others. They will then create a flower in the hallway using these hands around the theme "When we unite for kindness, acceptance, and inclusion…That’s when we grow!"

Congrats to Ralston High School students (from left) Derick Vasquez (senior), Chadwick Myers (senior) and Tyler Richardson (junior) on making All-State Orchestra and Choir. Derick and Chadwick were selected for All-State Choir and Tyler was selected for All-State Orchestra.

Chadwick will also be a part of the 2019 All-National Honor Ensemble and will perform with students from across the county in Orlando, Florida on November 7th!

Each year, over 3,000 students from across the state audition for the Nebraska All-State Band, Chorus, Jazz Band and Orchestra. Tyler will play percussion and will be one of 130 students selected to perform with the All-State Orchestra. Derick and Chadwick will be among the 440 students selected to be part of the All-State Chorus.

The All-State Jazz Band and Choir concert will take place at 1:30 pm and the All-State Orchestra and Band concert will start at 7:30 pm on Saturday, November 23rd at the Lied Center for the Performing Arts at the University of Nebraska - Lincoln.

October 16, 2019 at 7:49 PM · Ralston, NE ·

What an amazing experience for students today at the College & Career Day at Ralston High School. Throughout the morning, the entire gym was filled with sophomore, junior and senior students visiting with over 30 regional college and university representatives and area business leaders.

Also, sophomore students were able to take the PreACT, while juniors were able to take the PSAT and the ASVAB.

Senior students gathered at the football stadium to take their annual all-class photo, then participated in the Apply 2 College campaign through Education Quest by filling out college and scholarship applications. They also attended a "Full Potential" motivational presentation by former Husker Demoine Adams.

Local business leaders, representing a variety of career paths, talked to freshman students about their industry and the jobs available. Students were also able to take part in fun activities during each presentation.

Thanks to all the colleges, universities and local businesses who helped make this day such a memorable one for our students.
